I hope everyone had an amazing holidays and a great start to 2025! I wanted to return with a "warmup" question that would get me back into discussion about sheaves and related matters, which is what I what to start off with. This question is inspired by the previous discussion (namely, that related to the topological topos) in which some of the elements were touched on but not explicitly brought up, but now I want to fully clear the air about this!

The Yoneda lemma gives us a clear view on what the objects of a category of presheaves are: they are those that are "testable" or "probeable" by the objects of the original category. This means presheaves can be seen as "generalized objects" of the original category that can be described by being probed by maps into them from "test objects", and thus by the maps into it from the representables in the full presheaf category. On the other hand, the "co-Yoneda lemma" gives us a completely and entirely different perspective on what the objects are: they are objects that are "locally modeled" on "test objects" of the original category; that is, they are the objects of the original category "glued together". So we have two different perspectives: the Yoneda perspective based on maps out of representables, and the co-Yoneda perspective based on taking colimits of representables.

These two perspectives seem completely irreconcilable on face value: what does maps out of an object have anything to do with taking colimits of those objects? But the recent discussion on the topological topos made me realize some things. One can think of the objects in the topological topos as sequences "glued together", and every morphism out of the representable can be thought of as "picking out" a sequence in the object. This made me wonder if there's any connection between the canonical projection morphisms out of the representables produced by taking the colimit, and the Yoneda perspective on what the maps out of a representable are supposed to be doing. So that's my question: is there any connection between these, and more generally, how am I supposed to reconcile the Yoneda and co-Yoneda lemma on both a mathematical and conceptual/philosophical level? Thanks for your help!

I actually do find these two perspective to be extremely consistent with each other.

first, the statement of the co-yoneda lemma as usually mentioned is very unsatisfactory to me, as it says that every presheaf is a colimit of representables, but not what the colimit is. Here's my pov: for a presheaf P P P, you get P(X) P(X) P(X) its X X X-shaped points for X X X an object of the base category. If you have a morphism of shapes X→Y X → Y X→Y, then you can transform Y Y Y points in X X X points by reparametrization. This is all stuff you already know, but I always like to insist on the notion of shaped points.

The yoneda lemma says that the universal X X X-point exists as an object, and is just yX yX yX. The co-yoneda lemma then simply says that if you have an object, it is just the gluing of all its points seen as their own standalone spaces, whatever their shapes. You take the colimit over the category of elements of P P P; in that category morphisms represent equality of points up to reparametrization.

Ok, I think I'm following. So it seems it's about points: a presheaf can be determined by gluing all of its points together (not sure what that follows from, maybe some basic property), and since a universal "point" for some object is given by the representable (Yoneda), it means that a presheaf can be determined by a colimit over representables (co-Yoneda). Since we are gluing one representable for each point of the presheaf, it means that the sum total of all canonical projection morphisms from the diagram of the colimit will be the same as the sum total of all the points of the presheaf. Yoneda then tells us that these are in correspondence with all natural transformations from representables to the presheaf. So that would confirm that the projection morphisms from co-Yoneda do align with morphisms out of representables from Yoneda. Anyways I hope I am understanding!

Oh this is very interesting, I didn't know we could interpret Yoneda this way.
Let me unfold the idea to see if I understand correctly.

Generally speaking, a morphism X→YX \to YX→Y is thought as a XXX-shaped point of YYY (a general element).
A presheaf PPP on some category CCC can be understood as a generalized space.
An element x∈P(X)x \in P(X)x∈P(X) is thought as a map x:X→Px : X \to Px:X→P. Hence, P(X)P(X)P(X) is the set of XXX-shaped points of PPP.

With this interpretation, the presheaf yXyXyX is a generalized space.
The Yoneda lemma states that the maps yX→PyX \to PyX→P (i.e. natural transformations from yXyXyX to PPP) naturally correspond to elements of P(X)P(X)P(X).
In other words, the generalized space yXyXyX classifies the XXX-shaped points. I.e., yXyXyX is the universal XXX-shaped point.

The category of elements of PPP can be seen as a sort of "over category of PPP".
The elements of PPP are the XXX-shaped points of PPP, with XXX varying among the objects of CCC.
In the picture, x∈PXx \in PXx∈PX, y∈PYy \in PYy∈PY, f:X→Yf : X \to Yf:X→Y is an arrow in CCC, and commutativity of the diagram means that P(f):y↦xP(f): y \mapsto xP(f):y↦x.
image.png

This makes PPP look like a cocone over CCC.
The co-Yoneda lemma can be interpreted as saying that this "cocone" is actually a colimit.
I think this can be made a bit more rigorous by considering the diagram of presheaves
image.png

In other words, PPP, seen as a generalized space, is the gluing of all its XXX-shaped points.

Am I making a mistake somewhere?

If we take CCC to be the "walking graph category"
image.png

then a presheaf GGG on CCC is a graph.

  • GVGVGV are the VVV-shaped points of GGG, i.e. the vertices of GGG.
  • GEGEGE are the EEE-shaped points of GGG, i.e. the edges of GGG.
  • yVyVyV is the graph with a single vertex
  • yEyEyE is the graph with a single edge (and its source and target vertices)

The Yoneda lemma says that the vertices (resp. edges) of GGG naturally correspond to the graph morphisms yV→GyV \to GyV→G (resp. yE→GyE \to GyE→G). On the other hand, the co-Yoneda lemma says that any graph GGG is made by gluing vertices and edges together.

This is so nice!

Yes, I admit I was also keeping the topos of directed graphs as a running example in the back of my mind when trying to think through this. It's a very simple yet powerful example of these principles!
I've only worked through part of this thread, but just wanted to say - this thread is really helping me intuitively understand the Yoneda lemma in way I hadn't managed before!

For example, I think I've learned that we have [Cop,Set](y(−),X)≅X[C^{\mathrm{op}},\mathsf{Set}](y(-),X) \cong X[Cop,Set](y(−),X)≅X in [Cop,Set][C^{\mathrm{op}}, \mathsf{Set}][Cop,Set]. Intuitively this says that an arbitrary presheaf XXX on a locally small category CCC is determined up to isomorphism by how it relates to the objects in the image of the Yoneda embedding yyy.

This is especially helpful, because we can think of y(c)y(c)y(c) as being in many ways like ccc. That's reasonable to do because the objects in the image of the Yoneda embedding relate to one another in the same way their corresponding objects in CCC relate in CCC. (We have [Cop,Set](y(c),y(d))≅C(c,d)[C^{\mathrm{op}}, \mathsf{Set}](y(c), y(d)) \cong C(c,d)[Cop,Set](y(c),y(d))≅C(c,d) in Set\mathsf{Set}Set for all objects c,d∈Cc,d \in Cc,d∈C).
(And I haven't even worked through the discussion on the co-Yoneda lemma yet! I'm excited to read through all this!)

I also love the idea that we can gradually learn what some X:Cop→SetX:C^{\mathrm{op}} \to \mathsf{Set}X:Cop→Set is like by studying natural transformations to it from objects in the image of the Yoneda embedding. That suggests there might be a way to gradually build up an understanding of XXX in a way parametrized by the objects of CCC. (This especially catches my attention for possible application to imaging!)

@David Egolf I got this "aha" moment this morning, so much that I want to apply this point of view to every situation :smile:

So let's try with imaging. Let's say we are analyzing a radiography.
As a radiologist, I am looking for the presence of specific shapes.
Let CCC be the category of those shapes I am interested in. For instance, there is a shape "human skeleton", "hand skeleton", "long bone", "small bone", "joints", and so on. These shapes are related by morphisms: a skeleton contains bones, a long bone has two ends, etc.

When doing a radiography analysis, I record for every shape XXX the set PXPXPX of instances of XXX in the image.

  • P(long bone)P(\text{long bone})P(long bone) is the set of instances of long bones present in the image: bone number 1, 2, etc.
  • P(hand skeleton)P(\text{hand skeleton})P(hand skeleton) is the set of instances of hand skeleta present in the image.
  • and so on

And I have functions between those sets, e.g.,P(long bone)→P(hand skeleton)P(\text{long bone}) \to P(\text{hand skeleton})P(long bone)→P(hand skeleton) that specifies which long bones belong to which hand skeleton.

Hence, the presheaf PPP is really a structured summary of the actual image.

Now, I also have, say, the presheaf yhand skeletony_{\text{hand skeleton}}yhand skeleton​ (yoneda embedding of the shape "hand skeleton").
We can think of it as the structured summary of an image of a hand skeleton.
A natural transformation yhand skeleton→Py_{\text{hand skeleton}} \to Pyhand skeleton​→P is a way to map this image of hand skeleton to my first image. The Yoneda lemma states that there are as many such natural transformations as there are hand skeleta in my first image.

Finally, the co-Yoneda lemma states that the structured summary of my image is made of instances of those bones and joints glued together.
Oh, this category CCC should be called the "walking human skeleton".

Note Yoneda lemma holds in much greater generality than presheaves, while CoYoneda is a bit more characteristic. Indeed, consider your category CCC presented as a monad in span C1⇉C0C_1 \rightrightarrows C_0C1​⇉C0​. Equivalently, this induces a monad YYY on Set/C0\textbf{Set}/C_0Set/C0​, sending a bunch of C0C_0C0​-indexed data to the free presheaf obtained by freely adding all the functorial action coming from the morphisms of CCC. Notice that Y(1→xC0)Y(1 \xrightarrow{x} C_0)Y(1x​C0​), is exactly the representable presheaf at x∈Cx \in Cx∈C, so the representable are the free presheaves on the very particular generators given by elements of C0C_0C0​. These are particular because they generate Set/C0{\bf Set}/C_0Set/C0​, meaning that, obviously, one can distinguish C0C_0C0​-indexed sets by looking at their value at each element. So Set/C0(x,P)=P(x){\bf Set}/C_0(x, P) = P(x)Set/C0​(x,P)=P(x) already at this level. Then algebras of any monad TTT on Set/C0{\bf Set}/C_0Set/C0​ inherit the same property, since Alg(T)(Fx,Q)=Set/C0(x,UQ)=UQ(x){\bf Alg}(T)(Fx, Q) = {\bf Set}/C_0(x, UQ) = UQ(x)Alg(T)(Fx,Q)=Set/C0​(x,UQ)=UQ(x). So Yoneda is not so much about categories as it is about general algebra over a base.

Similarly, co-Yoneda already holds for Set/C0{\bf Set}/C_0Set/C0​, since P=∑x∈C0Px⋅xP = \sum_{x \in C_0} Px \cdot xP=∑x∈C0​​Px⋅x where ⋅\cdot⋅ is [[copower]] and xxx denotes again the generator 1→xC01 \xrightarrow{x} C_01x​C0​. In fact I believe the only monads with this property are free presheaf monads, ie the ones arising by pull-push along the graph of a category, thus characterizing categories!
Indeed, a coproduct-preserving monad on Set/C0{\bf Set}/C_0Set/C0​ is determined by its value on the generators, thus we can write TP=∑xPx⋅TxTP = \sum_x Px \cdot TxTP=∑x​Px⋅Tx. Peva Blanchard said:

So let's try with imaging.

Yes, the kind of thing you sketch above is similar to what I had in mind! Except the "walking" category I was considering wasn't a category relating something like different bones. Instead, I was considering a category which relates different ways or places in which we can perform sensing. So, for example, the objects might correspond to different collections of sensors, or different angles of transmission. Then arrows in this "walking" category correspond to relationships between different ways of sensing.
(I'm not fully happy with the idea that our image is a presheaf from this "walking" category of related sensing ways/places. But that's probably a topic for another thread at some point!)
